Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2014 05:55PM Crone wrote: Just received an email from the local Breast Cancer Group inviting all survivors to a light the site for community gatherings and festivals to light the area pink. Â It invited survivors but also said they would remember those who have been lost to the disease. Â  Maybe I am being sensitive but I feel a bit lost or should I say not included as someone dealing with Stage IV. Â When they ask the survivors to stand up to be acknowledged I guess I could think well I'm still alive so I guess I'm surviving but I don't think that's what they mean
Posts.Title: First Puketober sitings! surfdreams sas-schatzi

Posts.Content: Crone wrote: Last dose of Xeloda was mid November and my feet are still peeling and finger tips still very tender. Does anyone know how long Xeloda stays in your system causing side effects. Now on Gemzar, had first dose and had to skip second dose for low counts. Second dose Wed. (Port has fibrin sheat so could not draw blood, will have TPA put in port nest week to dissolve it, hopefully. Only one good vein left!) but other than a few aches the only issue I am having is with my finger nails. If I pick up something as simple as a pillow, the nail will bend back and break about a 1/2 inch from top of finger making for very sore and stubby nails. Any suggestions if this is side effect, vitamin defficiency or just living with cancer. Hope everyone had a wonderful Christmas and could forget about their diagnosis for a few hours and enjoy the day Surgery 1/10/2001 Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel, Underarm/Axillary; Mastectomy: Right Chemotherapy 2/4/2001 Adriamycin (doxorubicin), Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Fluorouracil (5-fluorouracil, 5-FU, Adrucil), Taxotere (docetaxel) Chemotherapy 3/13/2001 Taxotere (docetaxel) Radiation Therapy 7/24/2001 Breast, Lymph nodes Chemotherapy 10/9/2001 CMF Hormonal Therapy 4/1/2002 Arimidex (anastrozole) Hormonal Therapy 4/5/2013 Aromasin (exemestane) Hormonal Therapy 6/19/2013 Femara (letrozole) Hormonal Therapy 9/13/2013 Faslodex (fulvestrant) Targeted Therapy 6/5/2014 Afinitor (everolimus) Chemotherapy 7/17/2014 Xeloda (capecitabine) Chemotherapy 12/10/2014 Gemzar (gemcitabine) Targeted Therapy 12/22/2015 Targeted Therapy Chemotherapy Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Chemo side effects, old and new Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2014 06:24AM Crone wrote: Thanks for the suggestions and advice. I will try the vinegar and warm water and also the hard nails. The "good" thing is that all ten fingernails have all broken and so I have no choice but to keep them very short. Amazing what we use our nails for without thinking. Hopefully the TPA will work and the port can be put to full use. Thirteen years ago, during first cancer, I had a Hickman Catheter that would not allow blood to be drawn from it so it seems to be my silly body causing the issues. For those on Gemzar, what is your cycle. My first plan was three weeks on,one off, but counts were too low for second dose so we skipped a week. The plan now is two weeks on at a lower dose, one off, so we will see if that works. We had planned to be in Florida for two weeks and now don't know whether to go for one week or just skip treatment and go for two. MO on vacation so can't get her advice. The trip is more for DH than me but can't say I wouldn't benefit from listening to the waves and hopefully feeling some sunshine. If you messed around with your schedule, did you have any adverse effects?
Posts.Title: Chemo side effects, old and new Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Crone wrote: Just need to vent. Friday brought the newspaper with a 16 page PINK insert for breast cancer awareness month that had only one mention of 40,000 who die each year from Invasive Breast Cancer but not one mention of Metastatic Breast Cancer. Then , my two sisters arrive to "support me" and did nothing to help for the entire weekend but sat and watched while I prepared meals and cleaned up. There was no mention of my MBC until I brought it up and then they told me that they don't tell any of their friends about "my condition" because they don't want to scare them. Now here it is Sunday, sisters just left leaving tons of laundry, and beds to be made and the NFL is on the tv wearing pink shoes, pink gloves and the ref's are using pink flags. I don't know what to say but hope that I am developing an aversion to pink. Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2016 05:16PM Crone wrote: Sending positive thoughts your way, Maureen. We all understand the anxiety but you are feeling it and I wish there was something to say or do to make it better. Hopefully your liver is having a funeral for dead liver cells. Hope your chemo goes well Woke up yesterday with bad headache and chills but since our daughter had taken the day off and I know how much work sub plans are ( she teaches first grade) I got ready to wig shop. It was wet and cold which didn't help and by 1 o'clock, I had to go home. Slept three hours and woke up with a temp of 101.4. Off to the ER where they did a bunch of tests and sent me home. Have you ever felt as if the interest in what is wrong with you changes when they hear you have MBC. Today I still have headache and slight fever - maybe it is a virus. As I spend the day on the sofa, I will send warm thoughts to each of you
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: May 13, 2016 06:34PM Crone wrote: it has been several weeks since I posted; I am still on Haleven and the good news is that it is working. Jennifer I particularly wanted you to know about the results. My tumor marker dropped 1000 points in one month and CT scan indicated fewer and smaller liver tumors. Haleven has not been an easy treatment for me but a woman who is being treated for Sarcoma at the same center is tolerating it well. Three years of treatment has taken its toll and Currently I am taking a two week break with the hope of feeling "more normal" before going back to treatment. Jennifer, I wish you good results and also hope that the women who have moved onto a different treatment are doing great!
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2014 02:45PM Crone wrote: Post Script. Â I could not live with out my computer and cell phone ( well I guess i could live but I would miss them). Â I stay in touch with family and friends through Facebook and email and texting and ready to take on Twitter.
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2015 11:01PM Crone wrote: Thank you for bumping this. I sat with my I pad this morning thinking about posting something about "fitting in". I read many of the posts but really, compared to those younger who face this disease, I have little to complain about and so mostly, I read and don't post. There is no support group in this area and no palliative care programs. I have supportive friends but they don't understand how isolating this disease can be. I would love to be able to talk with others close in age about looking at the side effects of chemo compared to just letting the disease run its course and other issues we face. The last time I posted, I was on Xeloda but developed Subacute Cutaneous Lupus Erythematosus ( a rash related to Lupus) so the Xeloda was stopped, a port put in and I am on Gemzar. My blood counts keep dropping so we haven't developed a good schedule but the MO just added Neulasta so counts should stay up. Hope others will post so that those of us who are "older" can support each other.
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Crone wrote: In searching for a place where I feel I might find people with similar needs, I have noticed that some time back (years for one and months for another) there have been threads started for people over 60 and over 70. Â Both have a few posts but then they seem to stop. Â  I belong to the over 70 group but until the breast cancer returned in liver and bone, I was and extremely active person. Â My daughter in laws said I could outwork them but things have changed and slowed down now that I am dealing with bone and liver cancer. I know I can post on any of the threads and have on the Afinitor and Xeloda ones but I feel so bad complaining when I read the posts of the young ones who are dealing with this disease every day of their life and fighting to have a long life meanwhile holding down full time jobs and taking care of families.. Â  Nothing I have to face is anything like what they face every day, Â I would stop all treatment if I thought my doing so would save someone younger from this disease. So my question is, where are the "elders"? Â How are they handling side effects and decisions about quality of life vs. quantity of life. Â Maybe they have it all together and don't feel the need for support from others but I admit I need to share with others who are experiencing the same or similar things. Â Yes, I have a supportive family and friends but no one who know's what it is like to live with this every day. Â  I went to the BC support group in town but they were all newly diagnosed and I think that they felt uncomfortable with my being there. Â When I called to join an exercise group for women with BC, I was told that I would be welcome but maybe I shouldn't share my story. So I truly hope there is no one else in their 70's with MBC but I am not foolish enough to believe that, so I hope a few will post. Â Otherwise I will continue to be a lurker, reading what other's post and learning from them. Â I will still post if I have a question but not with complaints because compared to all of you who are younger, I have nothing to complain about. Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2015 11:42AM Crone wrote: Yesterday I saw the MO to review PET scan and "where do we go from here". We were totally overwhelmed when she called last week to say that there was no evidence of disease in the bones, liver and lymph nodes. Xeloda and Gemzar kicked them hard and hopefully for a long time. Finding articles on what is next after NED was not conclusive so I had to be patient ( not one of my strong points when it comes to health information). Anyway the MO said that the Standard of Care in not to change what is working so I will stay on Gemzar two weeks on and one week off. I think I knew that would be the case but I had let my mind dream about having less fatigue, not planning around chemo and being concerned with low blood counts. So the news is really great and I will really try not to complain about crummy collateral damage. Wishing all of you a time with NED. I have had 4 PET scans in the past year with no objections from Medicare and supplemental which is an Advantage Policy. The MO said they have more trouble getting them for diagnosis than re staging. Who knows, maybe it is if the insurance contact is in a good or bad mood that day. My MO also asked when the PET report came on My Chart, it was 5 days after test. She said that it is automatic and the Dr's have no contol over there release. She is like me in wanting to get her results right away but there apparently was an incidence when a patient read her biopsy report before the surgeon and when the news was bad, she was understandably upset so the whole procedure is under review. My theory is if you don't want to know, don't look but that might be a bit harsh. Yesterday was chemo and Dexadron day so being a bit wired,I best quit before I am banned for sharing t.m.i.
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2015 03:17PM Crone wrote: Three primary tumors is way too much for any one person. You have been through a lot. I am glad you are NED and hope you stay that way for a very long time. When ever there is anything new or a change in treatment, our kids seem to rally around but other times their expectations of "normal life" seem to prevail. This weekend I received an email from DIL saying how incredible it is that I feel so well and that I am very lucky. This happened to be the weekend after second week of chemo when I simply can't stay awake. I try to keep going but if I sit down, I am immediately asleep. This is accompanied by a deep depression and this is "incredibly lucky ". I'm not sure if our family and friends see us as they want us to be or if they are in denial. I am thankful that we can support each other here as I have learned not to look for support from family and even more so with friends who all seem to have their own physical issues. Maybe we all need to be more forthcoming about what we need but so far I haven't found that to work. I agree about how difficult this is (I tend to feel more compassion for anyone who is younger than me and is facing this disease) for the young ones and so wish for a cure or even more hope. No matter our age, we still want to be part of life, be appreciated and be cared about. It is part of being human and having real needs.
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2015 02:18AM Crone wrote: Hi Barb 312, I believe I remember you also; I think I remember you also had some connection to Indiana Glad to hear that you are doing well except for fatigue, but isn't that the new normal for so many of us. Could we all schedule an appointment with your oncologist; even if he lied and took a few years off my age I'd be ready to dance. Have any of you read the blog titled ( I think) Philadelphia Story about the women who attended The Living with Breast Cancer Conference in Philadelphia last weekend. They did a " die in" to represent the 108 people who die daily from Metastatic Breast Cancer. The blog was very emotional and once again brings home from the devestation of this disease. I post on Facebook mainly to keep up with family spread across the country. I posted the story about the "die in" earlier today and last time I looked no one had liked or commented - it is easy to understand what this disease seems to be ignored. Hoping for a good tomorrow for all.
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2014 02:43PM Crone wrote: My body seems to feel older each day ( since I started Xeloda) but my mind does not think or accept that I am 74. Â  I have trouble reconciling what I want to do with what I can do, always pushing a bit harder and then being so tired I could cry. Â We have planned to visit family on my week off from Xeloda which means going somewhere every other week while the weather is warm. Â This sounds wonderful but I am wise enough to know that I will be exhausted trying to stay up late with the older grands and getting up early with the little ones who show up next to my bed saying Nana, Nana. Â How can you miss that no matter how bad you feel? I also struggle with the amount of money it costs to treat this illness. Â Yes, I want to live and yes I think staying alive is worth the cost (physical and monetary) but the "just" side of me says the $7000 in copay for medication the last three months could do so much good for others. Â Instead of paying for medicine and copays for seeing the Onc. every other week, we could help pay college tuition or help someone who is struggling with paying their mortgage. These are things that weigh heavy on my mind during the quiet times or the times I can't sleep. Â They are things I think about when I read the thread of those who have chosen to stop treatment and wonder if and when I should join them. But for now, I will keep doing what I am doing and know that I will know when the time has come to make this decision. Do any of the younger women who have read and posted have any suggestions on how we can help you. Â I tried to start a giving tree at the Onc Center last year but it did not have many interested in helping. Â I realize when we are dealing with our own illness, it may be the only thing we can focus on. Â  Having time to reflect and evaluate are one of the many gifts of retirement. I wish that all MBC patients will reach the age of 74 and have the opportunity to be retired not because they are on disability but because a cure has been found and they have managed to beat this disease and can enjoy the fruits of their labor. Please know that all of you are in my thoughts and prayers.Â
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2014 07:35PM Crone wrote: I am on Medicare with a Medicare Advantage Plan. Â I would have/ should/ have checked into it a little better but when we signed up, I was without the MBC diagnosis. Â The monthly cost is low but there seems to be a copay for everything. Â It is $10 for primary care but $40 for specialists. Â The copay for Afinitor put me into the Medicare D donut hole and of course we expected that the second copay would move us out of it but I was changed to Xeloda which is covered by Medicare and is a 20% copay. Â The interesting thing is that now that I am in the donut hole my usual Rx. cost Â between $1 and $2 each when they were always at least $7 a piece. Â Read all the small print and beware if you are admitted to the hospital. Â Insist on knowing if they have you on Observation or truly admitted. Â If you are on observation, they only pay for 72 hours. Â I was admitted for a broken pelvis and even though I asked daily about my status, we ended up paying quite a bit. Â Insurance companies believe they need to have a healthy profit!
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2015 04:06PM Crone wrote: Very thankful and appreciate the kind words but I so wish that everyone could experience this, especially the very young. I too, have so much to live for but they have so much more to lose. Two days after chemo with fatigue, swollen eyes, red blotchy face and sore lips and the reality of life on chemo returns. But being retired allows me to try and adjust my schedule to accommodate. But no matter how I see myself in the mirror, I would wager at least one person will tell me how great I look today ( my DH just did) and so we smile and say Thank You. I am glad that this thread is staying "alive". I can be supportive and sharing on the other posts but hate to complain around the younger ones. Need to go buy a corned beef so we can prepare for St. Patrick's Day but without the green beer for me.
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2016 03:27AM Crone wrote: Good Sunday morning. The sun is shining and our temperature will be in the 60's this week. Hope this means and early Spring and the weather is not teasing us. Sorry about what you went through with the heart medicine Suzanne. Being light headed with the possibility of falling is scary. It is great your husband and daughters knowledgeable and can stay on top of things. My DH is a retired pulmonary and critical care physician. I have to remind him often that I need him to be my supporter not my Doctor but in his defense, he was the one who diagnosed the Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome. I will be anxious to hear about your hair loss. Hope the Coumadin keeps the blood clots away. Glenna, hope you are having a good weekend with your grandsons. Grandkids are one of the greatest blessings in life, we have six, five grandsons (ages 4-21) and one granddaughter. Three live in Idaho, two in Milwaukee (one is currently doing an internship in Washington DC. Our 11 year old grandson and his parents live near us which is a gift but now that he is in middle school, we don't see him very often, Maureen, what day is your scan? Want to send prayers and positive vibes your way - it is so hard to wait for results. My Day 1 is Tuesday. My anxiety level is up which is unusual for me, I can usually handle most things but knowing the list of options is getting shorter is not easy to think about. Nausea has been constant the past few weeks; I imagine the liver doesn't like the tumors and is letting my body know. Do you get Decadron before Halavan? I hate steroids, I describe myself as wired and tired for a day or two after getting them. We just moved in mid January to a retirement community. They are building condos and we moved into the first building - we are living in a construction zone. The workers arrive every day at 6:30 a.m. and want to be sure we know their here. Anyway, after we moved in, we kept finding bees that were dead or almost dead. Seems like there is a colony of bees in the rafters or walls of our unit. We were able to close the openings where they were coming in but our neighbor who is a bee specialist tells us they have to get the bees out or we will have honey dripping down our walls and when the hive deteriorates, it will destroy the wood and draw other insects. So much for carefree senior living. With the temperature rising the bees will become more active so it could be an interesting week, new chemo and bees. Glad that you all have kept this thread alive and that Halavan will be good to all of us. Phyllis (also known as Crone, a wise woman ((aren't we all))
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2016 12:17AM Crone wrote: Winter is returning with freezing temperatures at night and promises of snow flurries during the day, oh where is Spring? The reduced dose lowered the side effects and kept lab results good so I was able to have dose two of this round. Hoping the effects are minimal and this will work for awhile. Nine months on Gemzar was the longest time on any treatment, hoping for a new record. It is sad to see all of you leaving not only because the treatment has failed but also that there are so few of us. I asked the chemo nurse why there seemed to be so few on the drug and she said most people don't get this far on the list. I'm not sure that means we have been in treatment for longer or is it because we are going through the list faster. How are you doing emotionally? I find the ups and downs harder to handle. One week we are talking about stopping treatment and the next celebrating the drop in tumor markers. My husband gets so up and starts planning trips and I try to be excited but reality keeps pushing into my emotions. Usually I am pretty upbeat and hopeful but not right now. Maybe it is the grey skies I have been reading through the past posts to see who is moving on from Havalen.? If you are moving on, how long were you on Havalen? Hoping for blue skies and good results from whatever treatments we are on with minimal side effects. Phyllis
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2016 09:42PM Crone wrote: Grandchildren are a gift and blessing in our lives. Wishing you lots of hugs and joy with them. The only problem with the IPad is they beat me at all their games. I get a lot of Oh Nana when I can't do the simple game they do but it is so much fun. Gemzar worked for 10 months and once we found the right dose it only made me tired the weekend after treatment. Who knows if that is the chemo or your body just saying "give me a break" Second dose of Haleven started well but has me getting IV fluids and IV nausea medicine. Mouth sores and fever are also back. It seems as if everyone is moving on from Haleven; hopefully we will see each other's posts on other threads and keep in touch. Blessings on each of you, may you find joy in each day, peace in each night and a cure for this terrible disease called CANCER. All will be well
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2016 05:02PM Crone wrote: Gator gal, When wig shopping the other day, most of the wigs used three different hair colors to create a blend. I wonder if they could add some other hair to mix with your grandson's. Not sure that's possible but an idea. Hopefully the halfway house will be a perfect blend of care and understanding and accountability. Sending positive thoughts for strength and support. Maureen. How did the treatment go? Any results? Thought that fever broke last night but back today. Several mouth sores. Not sure how much longer I can or want to do this. Phylli
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2016 06:52PM Crone wrote: Dear friends, I certainly don't want to be a quitter and we are looking at clinical trials. It is my body that is quitting, don't mean to be dramatic but when you look at side effects and at the bottom of the list are the very rare side effects, that's what I get. Had to quit after one round of Afinitor, I did not have mouth sores but mouth craters. The breast cancer specialist had never seen such a reaction and insisted I stop. Next Xeloda, developed Acute subcutaneous lupus Erythematosis which can progress into full blown Lupus. On Gemzar, Hemolytic Uremic syndrome landed me in the hospital and off chemo for awhile. Anyhow, my body does not tolerate medicine well and all the side effects have taken quite a toll. I had a low grade fever for 10 days after first dose of Halavan, still have mouth sores and yesterday my hair started coming out by the handfuls. If my ANC is over 1000, I am going to try a lower dose after we get back from DC. Life is full of good things along with hard times and I want to keep going but I do need a reality check now and then. Suzanne, I appreciate your pep talk and will hang onto it when we face the decision to stop or continue the Halaven. Lovely picture Glenna; grandchildren are all wonderful but holding a baby one is very special and comforting. Both ladies in the picture are beautiful. I love her chubby cheeks. I have a goal to knit baby blankets and store them for when great grandchildren come. Have two scarves to finis first. Maureen, I hope the Gem/cis is a keeper for you. I was able to take Gemzar longer than any other treatment. It is interesting to look at the list of drugs we each have been on and the order we received them. Maybe it is what's on the "blue light special" that month. Once again, thank you for the support. It is so nice to have people to talk with who understand. Hopefully I will be in DC Thursday to Sunda enjoying family and cherry blossoms Phyllis
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2016 03:01PM Crone wrote:  We did make it to Washington DC and had a wonderful time visiting family and seeing the blossoms in their prime. Worth the fatigue!! So today is chemo day, or not. Pretty much had decided that I could not do another Halaven treatment between the low counts, mouth sores, etc. MO saying your body can't take much more and then my tumor marker dropped from 1400 to 1200. We have talked about this over and over. Unfortunately, MO on vacation so will need to see Nurse Practitioner. At this moment I am thinking of trying a reduced dose but I have until 1:20 p.m. To change my mind numerous times. Suzanne, I hope the tooth issue ends with removing the tooth. We all dread the possibility of ONJ so we will pray that it heals. Glenna, glad you had a good time in Florida with grands. I can't think of two things I enjoy as much as being with grandchildren and listening to the waves in Florida. Maureen, I hope the new treatment serves you well and is easily tolerated. I got nine months from Gemzar. The sun is shining although it is cool but days like this make living even more desirable. Phyllis
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2016 12:47AM Crone wrote: Happy Day todayðŸ˜ŠðŸ˜Š. At my pre - chemo visit with the Dr, she walked in with a big smile on her face and asked if I had seen my labs. They had not been posted on My Chart so I had nor seen them. Well my tumor marker dropped from 1180 to 280. Haleven is working. I feel like I have been given more time ( who knows how long but we will take each day). Knowing that it is working makes the side effects more tolerable How was the weekend with the Grandkids. Hope you had lots of fun but we're not too tired afterwards. How was the Abraxane, I have not read about the side effect - hope they are not too bad. Suzanne, It must have been difficult having a thoracentesis one day and Gemzar the next day. How did you do? Hoping that each of you have great results on your new treatment and we all have lots of "good days" Phyllis
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2016 10:42PM Crone wrote: Welcome Jennifer, but sorry you are needing to move on to a new chemo and wish you an easy time. Each one of us respond to each chemo in a different way so here is hoping your time with Halaven is a piec of cake I was told that they do not use Neulasta with Halaven because it takes longer then 7 days to respond so it would be past your second dose before white count would respond. They might consider Neupogen but that means daily visits for injections ( not like in 2001 when I would give myself the injection at home.) Please keep in touch. Glenna,I should have checked on line last night, I was awake from the Decadron at about the same time. Let us know about Abraxane. It is hard to say no to spending no to time with daily even if we know we won't have any time to rest and will be exhausted later (especially if we are facing another round of chemo Ina few days. Suzanne hoping for an easy time and a good result from Gemzar. Please let us now how you are doing.. Maureen, how are you? Thinking of all of you and hoping each of you have a " good news day soon" Phylli
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: May 29, 2016 03:49PM Crone wrote: Even though Halaven has given me some hard days, you have to stay with what's working. Tumor markers were 1300+ in February, they have been dropping since I started on Halaven. Tumor Marker this week is 89 and CT shows some shrinkage in liver tumors but a few additional bone involvement. So for now I am very thankful for this drug and hoping it works for everyone who is currently being treated with this drug. Hoping that those who moved on from this drug are finding good results on their new treatment. Thank to the Veterans who have served our country and those who are still serving
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2016 10:40PM Crone wrote: Halaven is not on my list of favorite breast cancer treatments, actually there are no treatments on that list. Eventhough Halaven has been hard on me, it is working. Feb. 29th, CA 27/29 was over 1400, yesterday it was 49 and that is with two dose decreases. Hopefully each of you, will have similar results
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2016 07:47PM Crone wrote: Have not posted often as my experiences with chemo has been to find the rarerest , seldom seen, side effects and make that part of my experience. I have had to stop half of treatments because they quit working and the other half due to side effects that came with the advice to stop the drug. I don't want to alarm anyone. After saying all that the Halaven was amazing. I had a short trial with Pablo but my platelets dropped to 35 and my tumor marker went to 1400. Halaven was started in March and after 30 days, t.m (Ca27 - 29 C) was 281 and dropped to 51.7 in July. Due to side effects, the dose had to be lowered twice and I am currently on the lowest dose. Side effects have been low counts, neuropathy of feet and hands, fatigue and one that isn't listed as a side effect, Mucositis of the colon. As my internist explained, the lining of the colon is like the hair producing cells and the cells in the mouth that lead to mouth sores. It was extremely painful and in NOT a usual side effect of the drug. My scan in July showed liver tumors shrinking, and bone mets healed. Unfortunately the last three tumor markers have been going up so I will have a scan on Oct. 13th, Metastatic Breast Cancer Awareness Day. I will go to the imaging center with copies of 13 things you should know about Metastic Breast Cancer to hand out to the staff. I wish I had a copy to hand the person who took my vitals yesterday. She asked how I felt and I said " like I had chemo last week". As she walked out the door she said "well it will be better soon" Wishing much success on Halaven to all of you, without the Mucositis, it might have been the easiest since hormone therapy.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Crone wrote: In searching for a place where I feel I might find people with similar needs, I have noticed that some time back (years for one and months for another) there have been threads started for people over 60 and over 70. Â Both have a few posts but then they seem to stop. Â  I belong to the over 70 group but until the breast cancer returned in liver and bone, I was and extremely active person. Â My daughter in laws said I could outwork them but things have changed and slowed down now that I am dealing with bone and liver cancer. I know I can post on any of the threads and have on the Afinitor and Xeloda ones but I feel so bad complaining when I read the posts of the young ones who are dealing with this disease every day of their life and fighting to have a long life meanwhile holding down full time jobs and taking care of families.. Â  Nothing I have to face is anything like what they face every day, Â I would stop all treatment if I thought my doing so would save someone younger from this disease. So my question is, where are the "elders"? Â How are they handling side effects and decisions about quality of life vs. quantity of life. Â Maybe they have it all together and don't feel the need for support from others but I admit I need to share with others who are experiencing the same or similar things. Â Yes, I have a supportive family and friends but no one who know's what it is like to live with this every day. Â  I went to the BC support group in town but they were all newly diagnosed and I think that they felt uncomfortable with my being there. Â When I called to join an exercise group for women with BC, I was told that I would be welcome but maybe I shouldn't share my story. So I truly hope there is no one else in their 70's with MBC but I am not foolish enough to believe that, so I hope a few will post. Â Otherwise I will continue to be a lurker, reading what other's post and learning from them. Â I will still post if I have a question but not with complaints because compared to all of you who are younger, I have nothing to complain about. Surgery 1/10/2001 Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel, Underarm/Axillary; Mastectomy: Right Chemotherapy 2/4/2001 Adriamycin (doxorubicin), Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Fluorouracil (5-fluorouracil, 5-FU, Adrucil), Taxotere (docetaxel) Chemotherapy 3/13/2001 Taxotere (docetaxel) Radiation Therapy 7/24/2001 Breast, Lymph nodes Chemotherapy 10/9/2001 CMF Hormonal Therapy 4/1/2002 Arimidex (anastrozole) Hormonal Therapy 4/5/2013 Aromasin (exemestane) Hormonal Therapy 6/19/2013 Femara (letrozole) Hormonal Therapy 9/13/2013 Faslodex (fulvestrant) Targeted Therapy 6/5/2014 Afinitor (everolimus) Chemotherapy 7/17/2014 Xeloda (capecitabine) Chemotherapy 12/10/2014 Gemzar (gemcitabine) Targeted Therapy 12/22/2015 Targeted Therapy Chemotherapy Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2015 02:59AM Crone wrote: After posting my question, I did an internet search on "How old is too old for chemo"? and was amazed at how many articles addressed this topic. Quality of life vs quantity of life seemed to be repeated in the articles. The pain that limits my activity is from a lymph node putting pressure on a nerve so not a side effect of the chemo and I can deal with the fatigue from the chemo. So I will stick with the chemo even if I end up being the senior - senior citizen at the infusion center. Maybe if I go there long enough, they will reserve a chair and parking place for me, kind of like the employee of the month.
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2015 07:25PM Crone wrote: The PET scanner is "portable" and in the back of what appears to be a semi trailer and it is always cold so I try to figure out all the layers I can put on that don't have zippers and buttons. I look a bit like a kid who has been stuffed in a snow suit by their mom. But the PET scans take much less time now then the first one I had in 2002. I most dislike not having any caffeine for six hours before hand. Hard to wake up without a little boost - yes I know it' isn't the best thing for me but I will try to be better in a few more years. I made the mistake once of saying I had seen my results of the tests on My Chart and since then the results are not posted until after I see the MO. I really prefer to get good or bad news when I am alone. It gives me time to accept what is rather then be surprised and have to make decisions without a lot of thought time. The holding of results may be a clinic policy but I intend to voice my dislike of that policy. This time I don't see the MO for a week and even thought I am anticipating positive news, I would rather not wait 7 days to find out. Besides my husband is a retired physician from the same clinic and I sometimes have to remind the MO and him that I am present and to include me in the conversation otherwise I am banning DH from appointments. I know they mean well but it is MY LIFE we're discussing What is everyone else's experience with getting results? I have heard that Medicare is limiting PET scans so I am a bit surprised this was approved. Anyone having issues with getting scans?
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2015 12:11AM Crone wrote: So I owe my oncologist an apology after complaining about having to wait for scan results. Less than six hours after scan, she called to tell me that liver mets, lymph nodes have shrunk and are barely visible. Bone mets seemed to be healed or healing. If it weren't so cold and icy I would be outside dancing. If and when you were stable or close to NED, did your treatment plan change? Even my orchid is celebrating.
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2015 09:18PM Crone wrote: It is 43 degrees and the sun is shining which makes having a good day easier. Thanks for posting about your encounter Sandilee; it gives us all hope and incentive to keep going at whatever pace we can manage. Not sure I will sign up for any marathons but a walk through a nature preserve might be nice. With two weeks on and one week off chemo, I try to slay as many dragons as I can in that off week.. Sometimes the dragons get the better of me . Today I figured out a computer problem that I had been fighting and with three days until treatment I feel empowered. DRAGONS BEWARE!
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2016 11:24AM Crone wrote:
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2016 12:51AM Crone wrote: I was almost finished with a long post when my niece called and when I came back it was gone. Too tired to recreate it now but will tomorrow. Want to send warm thoughts and hugs to Maureen for good news from tomorrow's scan! Will keep you in my prayers. Until I can make sense. Phyllis
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2016 10:57PM Crone wrote: Wonderful news about your son. Each day at a time and sometimes it is just a minute at a time. The halo sounds like a very good option. Chemo cancelled today, ANC 300 so labs next week but I do not want chemo as we hope to go to DC and at this time family is more important than chemo. We started " the stop treatment talk" today. Dr going on vacation for two weeks so we will evaluate when she returns
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2015 09:31PM Crone wrote: Love the comment about lots of hair. Still have hair but it is thinning from Gemzar. I remember years ago ( during primary diagnosis) taking off my wig in front of two grandsons. One said, put it back on while the other was laughing and wanted to try the wig on. They all respond differently. How old is too old to get chemo? Not sure why but as I was getting chemo today, I asked the nurse how old was their oldest patient getting chemo. She thought for awhile and said 78 or 79. This started me thinking and I wonder how long it is reasonable to continue chemo. Do you base it on how you feel or if it's working or does age fit into the decision? Interested to hear what others think.
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2015 12:03AM Crone wrote: Congratulations to those who are doing so well for so long - I wish this and more for everyone. I am also glad to see this thread alive again, I thought it was just getting buried deeper into the discussion and that I was the only one who wanted to connect with Stage IV women/ men who are older and dealing with issues related to this disease. I still think of myself as active as do my family and friends but not as active as two years ago when we had a five bedroom home and I quilted and gardened but I an finding new pursuits. Sandilee, thanks for asking about my ongoing pain issue. It is thought to a lymph node that is or was pushing on the Illei Ingual nerve causing right sided lower abdominal pain, radiating to the inner thigh and to the muscles in the hip. The node may have shrunk but may have caused permanent damage. The pain comes after walking a short distance or after standing. It is relieved after sitting with my feet up. Hard to do when trying to take a walk around the neighborhood, guess I could act like I am stretching out. Wednesday will be my first scan in 6 months, the MO was trying to establish a two week on one week off . Because of low counts, that took months until they added Neulasta.
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2015 09:21PM Crone wrote: Hi Teakie88 and thank you for your thoughts. Since I started this thread, I will speak about where I was coming from and still come from. I have posted on other threads/ topics especially when I have a question regarding a treatment or side effect. Where I struggle is with voicing my issues/ complaints when I have it "easier" then the young women who are facing this disease. This is not to say that my issues are any easier but as much as I want to continue living I have seen all our kids grow up, graduate from college, get married and have children. The young ones may never have that opportunity - what they face has to be so very much harder. They still have to work and car pool and comfort more than be comforted. If I am having a bad day, I can say to DH, your in charge of dinner. ( That may actually sound better then it is. We are talking about a man who spent most of his life on call and in the intensive care unit. He learned to clean a toilet at age 75 and is beginning to master chopping an onion. His notorious comment which I threaten to put on his headstone is "Housework can be strenuous". ). Back to the topic, all of you younger women and men deserve a cure, a chance to live a full, complete life. A chance to complain about joints aching from old age, not from chemo side effects. And yet I find I need support and community and this is one place where we all understand what the others are facing and I don't feel quite so bad saying I really feel bad today. Recently my DH who is a bit more traditional in his faith- spirituality than I, told me that he was praying to this person to cure me because that person needed one more miracle to be named a saint. I don't often get angry but this time I did. I said that is wrong, if you want to pray for a miracle then you pray for a cure for all MBC patients and not just for me. I think he understands now. So I think we all still post on multiple threads but ( I am speaking justfor me) saying this is hard to someone who is in a similar situation is more comfortable than saying this is hard to someone who has so much more to face than I do.
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2015 03:18AM Crone wrote: Welcome to all who have recently posted. It is good to hear your stories and know that there are others facing the same issues and being supported by each other. It will be interesting to hear about Ibrance/Femara as that could be the future drug for many of us. I hope they work for all of you. My last scan showed no evidence of disease recently after being in treatment for two years,but since then my tumor markers are creeping up, they have always been good indicators. Hearing I was NED was wonderful but then hearing I would continue on Gemzar two weeks on, one off took a bit of the joy away. Sometimes I find myself wondering which is worse, the disease or chemo. But life is good and there is beauty in each day. Today getting a call from grandson who is sophomore in college brought us unexpected joy.
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2014 08:15PM Crone wrote: So good to see someone post on this thread, I thought it might just fade away. Â So many times I am feeling the same emotions that others are posting but I know I have had a very good life having raised four children, watched them graduate, find someone to spend their lives with while contributing to society; it doesn't seem right to share my fears, sadness and pain when the young ones have so much more to loose. Â Yet those feeling are real and without support it can be a lonely time for us no matter what our age. Good luck with the Xeloda, I will start round five next week. Â TM dropped after two rounds so I am hoping next months scan will show that the liver mets are shrinking. Â I will be spending the next couple days sitting because the hand and foot thing is making it hard to walk.
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2015 01:57AM Crone wrote: A question for the "wise women or men". How do you or have you encouraged an adult child to face the reality of your diagnosis? We have four adult children, all with spouses and three with children. I can be very open with three of them but the youngest doesn't want to talk about my illness and has not told his older children (ages 9 and 12) about my diagnosis even though his daughter ( only grand daughter and we are close.) I'm ok with letting him be where he is but I hope he won't have regrets later. I would like to help him express his feelings but know I can't change him. I have participated in The Conversation Project and feel that I can be upfront with my wishes and desires with all but him. PBS has had some programs recently on cancer. One I just watched and would reccomend is Being Mortal featuring Atul Gawande, a surgeon and writer. He has written a book with the same name, Being Mortal ( medicine and what matters in the end) which is on my reading list. Still extremely cold in Indiana but currently no ice or snow - I am longing for signs of spring.
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2015 10:30PM Crone wrote: A little more levity for the day. So my hair decided it would thin and have some almost bare areas from the chemo, so decided that I would get it cut shorter and layered to try to hide some of the spots. Of course because I am still trying to keep hair my normal color so I was scheduled for color also. It was extra crazy at the salon because the salon is near a college campus and spring break started today and there were lots of young people getting hair cuts before they left for warmer places and I think they got a few laughs when they saw me after they took the towel off my head. Everything had gone well until we washed my hair, the color was perfect but my scalp was maroon. The chemo must be changing the skin and how it reacted to color. I sat there trying to look like of course this is what I wanted meanwhile thinking how hard my 10 yr old grandson would laugh tomorrow. Well thankfully, my super stylist came to the rescue put something on the scalp, had me sit for awhile and magically the color was gone. I may need to think about getting a new wig so I am prepared if this keeps happening.
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Crone wrote: After 12 years, it seems as if the cancer has returned. Had Mod. Radical Mastectomy ( tumor was 3.5 cm, grade 3, 110f 21 positive nodes) followed by 2 AC (cardiac side effects stopped the treatment) 6 doses of Taxol, 35 radiation treatments, followed by 6 CMF treatments. Now scans indicate spots on liver and in hip. PET tomorrow, liver biopsy next week. My questions are about treatments others have received for similar diagnosis. I've read everything from hormone treatment to radiation to chemo. Will not meet with Oncologist for 10 days so biopsy results can all be in. Surgery 1/10/2001 Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel, Underarm/Axillary; Mastectomy: Right Chemotherapy 2/4/2001 Adriamycin (doxorubicin), Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Fluorouracil (5-fluorouracil, 5-FU, Adrucil), Taxotere (docetaxel) Chemotherapy 3/13/2001 Taxotere (docetaxel) Radiation Therapy 7/24/2001 Breast, Lymph nodes Chemotherapy 10/9/2001 CMF Hormonal Therapy 4/1/2002 Arimidex (anastrozole) Hormonal Therapy 4/5/2013 Aromasin (exemestane) Hormonal Therapy 6/19/2013 Femara (letrozole) Hormonal Therapy 9/13/2013 Faslodex (fulvestrant) Targeted Therapy 6/5/2014 Afinitor (everolimus) Chemotherapy 7/17/2014 Xeloda (capecitabine) Chemotherapy 12/10/2014 Gemzar (gemcitabine) Targeted Therapy 12/22/2015 Targeted Therapy Chemotherapy Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Lots of questions Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2013 10:04PM - edited Apr 13, 2013 10:05PM by Crone Results from PET showed liver mets, lymph node involvement and questionable bone mets . Could not biopsy liver due to risk of bleeding so biopsied lymph node instead. Biopsy due back Tuesday. Can chemo be repeated? I had 6 Taxol and 6 CMF and see both drugs mentioned for liver mets and wondered if the are effective a second time. If you were meeting with Oncologist, what questions would you ask? I border between life being normal with family and friends, gardening and quilting and counting the days I have left.
Posts.Title: Lots of questions Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2013 01:15PM Crone wrote: Two days after meeting with Oncologist and still processing my thoughts. Life seems so normal and the hope is to keep it that way as long as possible. The tumors are breast cancer metastasis, Estrogen positive. Unfortunately, the needle biopsy did not provide enough tissue for any other analysis. Taking Aromasin daily and X Geva monthly, labs monthly and scans every 8 weeks. Seems like a bit of a bother but not life changing. Getting second opinion from breast cancer specialist next week. I think I can consider myself lucky that this was found so early and for now the treatment is tolerable. So we will continue to teach life management skills to my husband, take care of ourself physically and try to stay within my spiritual center. I am open to any suggestions, information that helps us as we once again walk this journey with all of you who find yourself on this path.
Posts.Title: Lots of questions Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2013 09:03AM Crone wrote: Thank you to all those who responded and offered support and information.Â Â I visited this site regularly for several years but then life returned to some sort of normalcy.Â  Now I find I am looking to this site once again and you have come to my aid.Â  The hardest part, as all of you know, is not knowing, not letting your mind wander to far with scary thoughts.Â  I can also question if I would be back here if I could have tolerated the AC or if I had stayed on Arimidex longer than 7 years; rationally I know that won't change anything, but I still wonder. Quotes of the day: From my husband who worked long hours for many years and is now retired: "house work can be strenuous". From my brother in law, when I told him what was going on: "I'm sorry but I have to have some more basal cell taken off my nose too. You have to love them and try to keep a sense of humor. Once again, thanks for your input and I will post when I have more information because I will need the support of those who are there and have been there. My new Mantra is :"I will be a hummingbird".Â  See the video below, you may need to copy it to your browser. http://www.karmatube.org/videos.php?id=2663
Posts.Title: Lots of questions Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Crone wrote: Just received this email (see below) from JLong at move on .org I'm sure that anyone who signed the petition will receive the same email but I am excited about this drug and wanted to post the good news. Thank you Dr. Suzanne Wardell for all your hard work on this drug. Email: Today I received via FedEx a letter from Pfizer - Vice President Corporate Affairs - Shreya Jani This acknowledgement letter really lifted my spirit that they took notice of our BZA petition. "Thank you for taking the time to contact Pfizer. We share your interest and concern in ensuring that our investigational agend bazedoxifene reaches those patients who may benefit. As you may be aware, bazedoxifene is currently used for the treatment of hot flashes associated with menopause and the prevention of post-menopausal osteoporosis. We are very interested in the results of Dr. McDonnell's per-clinical study of bazedoxifene in breast cancer cells and we are committed to understanding its mechanism of action. At the moment, Pfizer scientists are working closely with Dr. McDonnell and others to better understand the findings from this study and conduct appropriate preclinical experiments needed to help us make decisions on the next steps. Pfizer is committed to the discovery, investigation and development of innovative treatment options to improve the outlook for cancer patients worldwide. Again, thank you for reaching out to express your concern on behalf of patients with breast cancer. I am happy to follow up as we learn more." Surgery 1/10/2001 Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel, Underarm/Axillary; Mastectomy: Right Chemotherapy 2/4/2001 Adriamycin (doxorubicin), Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Fluorouracil (5-fluorouracil, 5-FU, Adrucil), Taxotere (docetaxel) Chemotherapy 3/13/2001 Taxotere (docetaxel) Radiation Therapy 7/24/2001 Breast, Lymph nodes Chemotherapy 10/9/2001 CMF Hormonal Therapy 4/1/2002 Arimidex (anastrozole) Hormonal Therapy 4/5/2013 Aromasin (exemestane) Hormonal Therapy 6/19/2013 Femara (letrozole) Hormonal Therapy 9/13/2013 Faslodex (fulvestrant) Targeted Therapy 6/5/2014 Afinitor (everolimus) Chemotherapy 7/17/2014 Xeloda (capecitabine) Chemotherapy 12/10/2014 Gemzar (gemcitabine) Targeted Therapy 12/22/2015 Targeted Therapy Chemotherapy Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 18, 2014 08:28PM Crone wrote: The Â most recent remark that made me stop in my tracks was said by my older sister. Â  When I thanked her for calling, saying that I had been having an anxious day as I wait for the next scan results and it was nice to know someone was thinking of me - she commented Â " well at least we now know your human". Â So this human will continue to deal with this disease with all this wonderful support.
Posts.Title: Lets do a Sh*t People say to Metastatic BC Patients Fitztwins ChicagoGirl

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2014 07:21AM Crone wrote: What chemo next? Just taken off Xeloda due to complications from the drug and wondering what are my options. First diagnosis, i was treated with AC until I developed Cardiomyopathy from it, then taxol for six rounds ( developed neuropathy in fingers and toes). Radiation and then six rounds of CMF. Arimidex for seven years. Metastasis discovered in spring of 2013. Started on Aromasin, after two months developed allergic reaction ( hives and face swelling.) On to Letrazole until it failed after four months. Faslodex added and remained on the combination for six months until that quit working. Next came Afinitor. After two days on it, I developed what was described as mouth craters. Sent to see breast cancer specialist, who said that since the side effect developed so early, I wouldn't tolerate a dose reduction. Xeloda was next and it was working, reducing liver tumors but the rash that started with first dose was biopsied and was a lupus type reaction that rarely turns into full blown Lupus but koncologist, dermatologist and rheumatologist advised it be stopped. I feel like I am crossing options off the list quickly. I have been scanning all your posts for treatment and it seems so many of you have Herceptin as part of your protocol but I an not Hr2 positive. I am searching the web for a list of drugs so that I have some idea of what is left and can make informed choices. MO is suggesting Gemzar next but I don't find many posts about it. It would be very helpful if some of the you with liver mets would post your drug progression. Just need more info in order to prepare for what's ahead. I also have bone and lymph node involvement.
Posts.Title: How are people with liver mets doing? blondie1 JFL

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2013 09:57AM Crone wrote: just saw where HLB posted this on "Did anyone else see this". Didn't mean to duplicate, must have been posting at the same time but some of us are just plain slow. You just can't share positive news too much!!!
Posts.Title: Bazodoxifene Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Crone wrote: My dh (retired physician) emailed this article from Medscape today. Â Thought the line in the second paragraph describing advance breast cancer patients as "a historically neglected population" one of the truest statements I have read in some time. The latest international consensus guidelines for the management of advanced breast cancer were published online September 18 in the Annals of Oncology and September 20 in the Breast. The advanced breast cancer 2 (ABC2) guidelines urge more research and clinical trials into treatment for advanced disease, and describe advanced breast cancer patients as a "historically neglected population." In particular, the guidelines note, more research is needed to find the best treatments for patients with breast cancer that has spread to the liver, pleural cavity, or the skin; patients with HER2-positive advanced breast cancer who relapse during or shortly after adjuvant treatment with trastuzumab; patients with stage IV disease; and men with advanced breast cancer who require treatment with aromatase inhibitors, such as anastrozole, exemestane, and letrozole. "Our plea is for strong commitment from everyone involved — academia, the pharmaceutical industry, funders, and advocacy groups — to develop well-designed, high-quality, multidisciplinary trials for advanced breast cancer," said guidelines committee cochair Fatima Cardoso, MD, who is director of the breast unit at the Champalimaud Cancer Center in Lisbon, Portugal. "This is of critical importance, as many questions are still unanswered relating to management strategies, better drugs and drug use, and individualizing treatments so that they are specific to a particular patient and their tumor," Dr. Cardoso said in a statement. The guidelines were formulated by a group of experts from around the world who met at the second International Consensus Guidelines Conference on Advanced Breast Cancer in Lisbon in November 2013. The conference was organized by the European School of Oncology with the goal to improve outcomes for all patients with advanced breast cancer. Some 1100 participants from 71 countries attended, and the new guidelines were codeveloped by the European Society of Molecular Oncology. The ABC2 consensus guidelines contain several updates to the first set of guidelines, which were issued in 2011. One new focus is on inoperable locally advanced breast cancer, which occurs in 15% of breast cancer patients in developed countries and in up to 60% of patients in developing countries. "There are very few clinical trials providing data for the best treatment of locally advanced breast cancer," Dr. Cardoso said. The ABC2 guidelines include new recommendations for triple-negative breast cancer, HER2-positive breast cancer, and hormone-receptor-positive disease. They also provide information gleaned from recent clinical trials on pertuzumab (Perjeta) and trastuzumab emtansine (Kadcyla) for HER2-positive disease and everolimus (Afinitor) for hormone-receptor-positive disease. "The care of women with metastatic breast cancer is highly variable around the world," ABC2 cochair Eric Winer, MD, director of breast oncology at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, told Medscape Medical News. "The guidelines that have existed, as far as I am aware, have largely been focused on the [American] population, or the United States and selected other countries. The ABC2 guidelines are designed to be useful to people around the world, in both economically advantaged and disadvantaged societies," Dr. Winer explained. He acknowledged that it might be difficult for the guidelines to be applied globally because of the disparity in resources that exist around the world, but many of them can be used regardless of a country's wealth. "On some level, one can think of some of these as aspirational in some countries. But we have set out certain basic principles, such as multidisciplinary care and palliative care, which are universally applicable," he said. The committee that wrote the guidelines only recommended treatments for which solid evidence exists, Dr. Winer reported. "We set forth what we thought would be the best possible care, and in some situations we were also able to make recommendations that in many societies would lead to somewhat less expensive care," he said. As an example, the guidelines suggest optimal frequency for imaging. Residents Salary & Debt Report 2014 View Report > "Sometimes imaging tests are done too frequently," he said. Suggesting that CT scans and other imaging tests can be done less frequently could save money yet still provide effective screening, Dr. Winer explained. The ABC2 guidelines also emphasize the importance of nursing and psychosocial care, in addition to medical care, in the treatment of a patient with advanced breast cancer. "These are patients who may live with this disease for many years in some situations, and for shorter periods of time in others, but there are real symptom management issues and psychological issues. If we are going to provide optimal care, it is going to take a number of different people to provide that care. Compared with the cost of some of the drugs we have, providing somebody with counseling and better symptom management may be well within the means of many countries," Dr. Winer said. Ann Oncol. Published online September 18, 2014. Full text Breast. Published online September 20, 2014.
